body:
Some simulations results: https://gist.github.com/achow101/edf6b5e308035a489fbb1f28d12e2109

I think the important thing to see here is that this is the same or better in every metric except for "mean UTXOs". But I think the thing to note here is that it's about the same mean UTXOs as the positive only effective value simulation. So I think the different there is primarily due to dust outputs that aren't being consumed.

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #18354 (Use shared pointers only in validation interface by bvbfan)
* #18011 (Replace current benchmarking framework with nanobench by martinus)
* #17458 (Refactor OutputGroup effective value calculations and filtering to occur within the struct by achow101)
* #17211 (Allow fundrawtransaction and walletcreatefundedpsbt to take external inputs by achow101)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->Needs rebase
<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->Needs rebase

<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->
ð This pull request conflicts with the target branch and [needs rebase](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#rebasing-changes).

<!--cf906140f33d8803c4a75a2196329ecb-->
ð This pull request conflicts with the target branch and [needs rebase](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#rebasing-changes).

Concept ACK. The results look promising!

> "Better" is defined as having lower fees. If the fees are the same, then the one that chooses more inputs (so consolidates more). If that is also the same, Knapsack is then used (i.e. Knapsack is preferred).

Since you already have a waste metric in BnB, have you considered using the waste metric to pick between the Knapsack and SRD?
`not_input_fees` is a bit hard to grok. How about `fixed_fees`, `payload_fees`, or `fees_excluding_inputs`?
Note to self: I assume this gets the minimum of the current fee rate and the 1008 block target.

Note to self: What was DiscardRate exactly? 

Why do you use `DiscardRate` here and not `long_term_feerate`?
I assume `positive_groups` pertains to the `spendable_utxo`?
I do not understand why they are called `OutputGroup`. I figure you are filtering each UTXO for whether it is economically spendable. How are these UTXO a group, and not just single UTXO?
`all_groups` here are all UTXO not just the economically spendable?

Shouldn't the 0 be the second outcome of the tertiary statement here?
If `coin_selection_params.m_subtract_fee_outputs` is truthy, shouldn't then the fee be deducted?
Aaah, are we talking about ancestry sets of outputs?
I'm curious, how come `coin.m_input_bytes` can be smaller than 0 here?

Wouldn't the above case where `coin.m_input_bytes` is smaller than 0 overstate the `effective_value` of the coin here? Would it not be better to set the `effective_value` of a coin whose size is haywire to 0 or negative here?
"Positive" is rather unspecific. How about calling this `GetSpendableGroup()`?
Isn't `coin_selection_params.effective_fee` a fee rate?

Nice clean-up. From what I understand, `actual_target` is the sum of the recipient outputs plus the precalculable overhead and output costs. If that's the case, maybe amend the comment to clarify that. What do you think of `selection_target` instead of `actual_target`?
diff_hunk:
@@ -48,28 +48,25 @@ struct {
  * @param const std::vector<CInputCoin>& utxo_pool The set of UTXOs that we are choosing from.
  *        These UTXOs will be sorted in descending order by effective value and the CInputCoins'
  *        values are their effective values.
- * @param const CAmount& target_value This is the value that we want to select. It is the lower
+ * @param const CAmount& actual_target This is the value that we want to select. It is the lower

body: I think that's a fee rate. Would not `effective_fee_rate` be then a better name?

Now that I think about itâ¦ assuming this is pertaining to a mode where the fees are deducted from the recipient output, and the output groups are considered with their actual values instead of their fee rates: have you considered the impact on the outcome for BnB selection? Would be kinda harsh if it suddenly considered all dust inputs spendable, burned a bunch of economically unspendable inputs and then deducted it from the recipient.
I've seen the witness element count been counted towards the witness block usually before. Are people now counting it to the transaction header? How come we are not counting in WU? :thinking:
I'm confused. Previously I thought that `m_subtract_fee_outputs` deducts the cost of the transaction from the recipient outputs. This comment seems to indicate that it's just the cost of the outputs.
Given that this would be 32 B, but a non-segwit change output could be 34 B, wouldn't it be more conservative to use 34 B? Can we rely that it will always use segwit addresses?
"change output"
Does Bitcoin Core not use BIP-69? Or will the outputs be sorted afterwards when the amounts are all fixed?
It's surprising to me that the `nFeeRet` could be lower than a minimum fee here. Wouldn't the fee rate on the input side of transaction building need to be bigger than `GetMinimumFee`?
Why did you overwrite `nFeeNeeded` with `nFeeRet` here?
diff_hunk:
@@ -2964,7 +2912,7 @@ bool CWallet::CreateTransaction(const std::vector<CRecipient>& vecSend, CTransac
     reservedest.KeepDestination();
 
     WalletLogPrintf("Fee Calculation: Fee:%d Bytes:%u Needed:%d Tgt:%d (requested %d) Reason:\"%s\" Decay %.5f: Estimation: (%g - %g) %.2f%% %.1f/(%.1f %d mem %.1f out) Fail: (%g - %g) %.2f%% %.1f/(%.1f %d mem %.1f out)\n",
-              nFeeRet, nBytes, nFeeNeeded, feeCalc.returnedTarget, feeCalc.desiredTarget, StringForFeeReason(feeCalc.reason), feeCalc.est.decay,
+              nFeeRet, nBytes, nFeeRet, feeCalc.returnedTarget, feeCalc.desiredTarget, StringForFeeReason(feeCalc.reason), feeCalc.est.decay,

body: The have the same scriptPubKey. IIRC it's for the avoid reuse stuff. Most of the time, they will be single UTXOs.
Yes.
Yes. It is a `CFeeRate`
This parameter is just generally all of the overhead, regardless of it's location in a transaction. It's in vbytes, which is `weight / 4`

`tx_noinputs_size` becomes `not_input_fees` later which ultimately increases the selection target so that the selection target covers the fees for the transaction. When subtracting the fee from the outputs, the selection target should not be increasing to cover the fees.
This is moved code, so I think it should remain as is.
No.
`nFeeNeeded` no longer exists. This should have been removed already. I probably forgot to rebase this branch.
diff_hunk:
@@ -2964,7 +2912,7 @@ bool CWallet::CreateTransaction(const std::vector<CRecipient>& vecSend, CTransac
     reservedest.KeepDestination();
 
     WalletLogPrintf("Fee Calculation: Fee:%d Bytes:%u Needed:%d Tgt:%d (requested %d) Reason:\"%s\" Decay %.5f: Estimation: (%g - %g) %.2f%% %.1f/(%.1f %d mem %.1f out) Fail: (%g - %g) %.2f%% %.1f/(%.1f %d mem %.1f out)\n",
-              nFeeRet, nBytes, nFeeNeeded, feeCalc.returnedTarget, feeCalc.desiredTarget, StringForFeeReason(feeCalc.reason), feeCalc.est.decay,
+              nFeeRet, nBytes, nFeeRet, feeCalc.returnedTarget, feeCalc.desiredTarget, StringForFeeReason(feeCalc.reason), feeCalc.est.decay,

body: @Xekyo This PR is built on top of 2 other PRs. It would be better to review those first as many of your comments are for the changes in those PRs. You should start with #17458, then #17331, then this one.
The default value is -1 to indicate that it isn't set.
How is Positive unspecific? The OutputGroup has only Positive effective values.
@achow101: Okay, I'll take a look at them.
